column2: In which course are you enrolled?
column3: Course design [The assigned readings have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column4: Course design [The RStudio primers have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column5: Course design [The Team Activities have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column6: Course design [The Learning Journals have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column7: Course design [The online class sessions have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column8: Course design [The Projects have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column9: Course design [The Learning Target Checks have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column10: Course design [The Blackboard course site is organized in a way that helps me to effectively navigate the course materials.]
column11: Instructor [The instructor is genuinely interested in my understanding.]
column13: Instructor [The instructor is available for extra help when needed.]
column14: What as been the best aspect of *this course* so far, and why?
column15: If there was one thing about *this course* that you would change, what would it be, and why?
column16: What is one thing that *you* can do differently to improve your learning? Explain how you plan to do this.
column17: Optional: Provide any additional comments that you feel that were not addressed by the above items or that you wish to expand upon here.

column14: I enjoy the activities. I also appreciate the professor's attitude. It makes me want to do well.
column15: The information can be overwhelming and seems like a lot sometimes. It can be a challenge to know how best to bite off smaller pieces or know how best divide and conquer topics to help them stick.
column16: Practice will be best, and practicing with intentionality. I think the amount to know will seem less overwhelming as I spend more time with it.
column17: I am enjoying the course and the challenge of it. I hope I can keep up!

column14: Collaborating and bouncing ideas off of peers in small groups is helpful.
column15: The learning journal requirement can be difficult to achieve an A in. Since we have two preparations a week and three learning journals should be completed in a week to receive an A and get to 43 total, it can be difficult to come up with something to write in the third learning journal for the week without repeating information from the previous two of that week.
column16: Practice more in order to not reference resources as often. I can do this by trying the practice problems from the book.

column14: The hands on exercises have been good for quickly learning the basics of ingesting and processing data.
column15: The organization of the course seems inefficient and confusing.
column16: I can try and adapt to the course structure.
column17: There seems to be a lot of emphasis on being very specific with how work is structured and submitted. But frequently there are either errors or clarifications needed in the assignments. It's been frustrating and things seem to keep popping back up that need further attention. The quantity of the learning journal requirement seem excessively high.

column14: How clear, well organized and efficient the processes in this class are. They have been very well thought out and all aid in learning.
column15: I don't mind the learning journals but I think doing only 1-2 per week would yeild more thought out answers and more time spent on them. I find trying to do 3-4 a week is a little much, I just don't know what to say for some but find myself trying to do them so that I work towards the goal number.
column16: I think that I could do the readings more carefully, I like the primers so I tend to skip by the reading a little fast.
column17: This has been a great course so far, my suggestions are only trivial and it is great the way it is

column14: The material covered so far in this course has been really interesting. I enjoy working with classmates on activities and learning with them
column15: While the course structure has been fun and engaging, I wish that some class time would be used for lecture format lessons. I feel like I'm learning everything from the primers and reading rather than from the instructor. I also wish that we could work through topics more quickly, and cover more material
column16: I could probably take some initiative to go out and learn about material related to the class on my own.

column14: The general design of this course is different from most courses, which I think makes it unique.
column15: I would like to be able to know how my overall grades are doing within the course, but I understand that that is not necessarily possible given the structure of the course.
column16: I don't think there is anything I can do differently to be more effective in my learning right now.

column14: The projects
column15: The Journals
column16: practice more on my own instead of in class

column14: Preparations: They have helped me to take notes early, so I can add to them while doing the activities. They also help introduce the material to me before working on harder problems.
column15: GitHub steps and final window screenshots. There are still times when I do a pull request and I am unsure as to what needs to be pressed or when to stop. I am unsure if I need to go one step further or if I have gone far enough sometimes.
column16: Take my time in understanding what is going on from one step to the next. I am still caught up in looking at examples and utilizing them as templates. This causes me to have to think about the more difficult problems longer than I would like. I will start to think about what I need to accomplish when I am given a problem. Then think about which functions can be used to accomplish those goals. Then finally putting it together, and only looking at examples when I forget where things go.
column17: This course is one of my favorites in the master's program. It challenges me to think with plenty of examples to help utilize the information we learn.

column14: How free and open the class feels, because it is nice to have that freedom to work at our own pace.
column15: More time for actual lectures with mini activities to check our understanding, because sometimes it feels like group members get left behind by others who are more experienced in the class.
column16: Look back at the book and primers after class to see where my understanding is at

column14: The RStudio primers are a great tool in preparing for the class session.
column15: The amount of learning journals required is overwhelming. I think one a week would be preferable.
column16: Spend more time on RStudio using different functions.

column14: The class activities
column15: lack of direct instruction on activities and concepts. When you are new to coding sometimes it is hard to know what questions to ask to get a better understanding.
column16: Do more practice on my own time with practice datasets

column14: I like how the learning target checks help me understand the material.
column15: Have the class preps due at 3:30pm instead of 2pm.
column16: Understand the primers better and redo them multiple times.

column14: We get to work on the activities in class which makes it easier to get help quickly when questions come up.
column15: I'd rather be in person because I have a hard time focusing on my classes when I'm on campus than I do when taking classes at home.
column16: Try to figure out the best way to lower distractions, and maybe try being in class somewhere other than my room.

column14: I really like the combined reading and primer assignments (the preparations). They're where I learn the most.
column15: I hate the group activities during class time! My connection is terrible and my group members rush to complete the activities during class time. Both of these things combined leave me in the dust.
column16: I need to be more organized and pay closer attention. I am working with a counselor to address the obstacles that get in the way.
column17: It was hard for me to assess how the materials provided have helped me meet the learning targets as I have not yet completed any of the learning target checks, so I have to assess for myself how well I think I can perform the learning targets...

column14: The team-based learning methodology is nice, once one gets used to it.  It's nice to leverage the strength of others, especially considering that tasks can be coded differently to arrive at the same outcome.  It's nice to share ideas to benefit from seeing how others might solve the same problem.
column15: Learning Journals - Although this is a tough one for me.  I really think they can be beneficial, I also often struggle with what to make them about and honestly am more doing them to check a box than anything else.  It's also been hard for me to engage with the GitHub community board.
column16: I think for me, the biggest thing has been time management.  I really enjoy the content, but I'm struggling trying to get used to my new life with a newborn, while working full time, etc.  I feel like I should have it dialed in the week after the class has ended.  I jest - but I'm trying to make sure I engage with the material every day, if even in small amounts, and that goes for both of my classes.  It's far easier to find a half an hour here and there than it is to find 4 hours on the weekend to cram a week's worth of material in.  It's just a matter of making sure I stick to it at this point.
column17: I think, naturally there are a lot of challenges that come into play with the pandemic environment we find ourselves in.  Having taken a team-based learning class before, I really think there is a HUGE benefit to being in person.  I understand that we just have to adjust, but I also appreciate how much work that can be to others, and myself of course.

column14: I think the structure of this class has been very helpful. I like how the preparations (readings/primers) allow us to read and practice some of the topics in a place that provides instant feedback before class. Then, I think the group projects are very helpful because it provides us another opportunity to work on the material we just learned and have discussions with our group members.
column15: I wish there was a bit more time dedicated to going over the material as a whole class at the beginning of lecture periods. I think that it would be helpful to have an open dialogue specifically about the topics of the days class period, even if it was a brief overview.
column16: I think the biggest thing I can do to improve my learning is utilizing the community github page to ask questions and get help on some topics that are still a bit confusing for me. I also need to utilize my private learning journal more often. I'll plan to do this by setting aside specific time before and after class periods to focus on writing out what I learned and what I'm still struggling with and reach out for help.

column14: Hands on and Khan Academy style flipping the classroom. Makes eventual proficiency highest priority.
column15: Lots of walls of text for so only much return. Parse the fat. Video recordings and other information compression techniques.
column16: Become more dependent on spaced repetition learning. Accomplish this by increasing frequency of learning journals to meet quota.

column14: Lecturer willingness to assist students to understand.
column15: Reduce the number of activities. limited time to revise effectively.
column16: Practice often. I would read and do the team work and assignment's again by myself .

column14: Working through R code collaboratively
column15: The grading mechanism is more complicated than it needs to be, it seems. I think it would be really helpful if each assignment had at the top or the bottom exactly the files we need to turn in, listed in bullets for ease of understanding.
column16: Pursuing additional learning including watching additional youtube videos and reading documentation

column14: I like the R prep activities a lot and the aspect of working on the activity in our groups.
column15: Nothing so far
column16: Have better time management skills with the activates and ask more questions about the activities to my group mates and instructor.
column17: Overall I really appreciate the structure of this class and I think it will have lasting impact in how I learn information from this class.

column14: Whole concept of learning checks has been good, nice that we get try multiple times if there are errors.
column15: I think it'd be better if we could do one learning journal at the end of the week and get a large amount of feedback over a weekly basis.
column16: Communicating with group more

column14: the option to resubmit work or retry learning target checks
column15: A comprehensive location or file with the information required to learn for the course. I feel like currently there are 3 or separates places to keep track of where I can find answers to questions, not including google.
column16: Rereview information more frequently.
column17: I feel like the information that we are tested on in the learning target checks or to finish the activities includes information that is not covered in the readings or primers. I understand that R is complicated and that there is a lot to cover and that finding information online is important to everyday working life. I also understand that problem solving when information is missing is also important, however I also feel I shouldn't be paying GVSU to teach me how to google things. Not that I haven't enjoyed the class, but that aspect has been very frustrating. Perhaps I have been missing a resource that might be helpful.

column14: I have enjoyed working through activities with my group
column15: This is not a big deal, but I would decrease the amount of learning journals we have to complete
column16: I feel like I should be reviewing the activities more after I complete them.

column14: I really like the proficiency grading aspect because it takes the edge off a little when trying to master the material. I can focus more on mastery and less on acquiring a certain amount of points on an exam or assignment.
column15: Being able to work ahead in the activities since we almost never finish on time.
column16: I can spread out the time I work on assignments in this class. Typically, I've been doing most of the work M-W, but it then leaves me having to remember to much after four days of almost no coursework. This might happen naturally as I start to work on projects on the weekends.

column14: Team Work
column15: Reduce Grading Complexity, The work load for this class is much higher than for other similar courses I have taken. The tasks are not very difficult, but the sheer number of different tasks and frequency of tasks is challenging to keep up with. I would suggest less tasks with greater difficulty.
column16: Spend more time doing the readings. It should help me understand the concepts in a deeper way. Plus repetition helps people learn
